LanguageData.WorldCameraMovement.label: World view camera movement
LanguageData.WorldCameraMovement.helpText: Zoom with the MOUSE WHEEL or {Key:MapZoom_In} and {Key:MapZoom_Out} keys.\n\nPan with the {Key:MapDolly_Up}-{Key:MapDolly_Left}-{Key:MapDolly_Down}-{Key:MapDolly_Right} keys, or by MIDDLE-CLICKING and DRAGGING.
LanguageData.ReformCaravan.label: Reforming caravans
LanguageData.ReformCaravan.helpText: After an encounter, you can easily re-form a caravan by using the RE-FORM CARAVAN command in the World view.
LanguageData.Rescuing.label: Rescuing
LanguageData.Rescuing.helpText: To rescue a wounded person, select a healthy colonist and then right-click on the wounded one.\n\nIf you rescue a non-colonist, they won't necessarily join your colony. They may simply walk away after healing. If you want to guarantee that they join, capture them and recruit them.
LanguageData.Capturing.label: Capturing
LanguageData.Capturing.helpText:
When an enemy is downed on the ground but not dead, you can CAPTURE them.

To capture, select a colonist, right-click on the incapacitated enemy, and select Capture.

You'll need an extra bed marked for prisoner use.
LanguageData.ShieldBelts.label: Shield belts
LanguageData.ShieldBelts.helpText: Shield belts stop ranged attacks from coming in or out. They have no effect on melee attacks.\n\nTo fight against shield belts, either concentrate a lot of gunfire on the target, or fight hand-to-hand.
LanguageData.InteractingWithTraders.label: Interacting with traders
LanguageData.InteractingWithTraders.helpText: You can talk to people with ? over their heads.\n\nSelect a colonist and right-click on the character with ? attached to his head.
LanguageData.Drafting.label: Drafting for combat
LanguageData.Drafting.helpText:
To control colonists directly for combat, Draft them by selecting them and hitting the DRAFT button.

A drafted colonist will do only what you tell them, and can only take combat actions. Those with weapons will use them when possible.

Don't leave colonists Drafted forever - they'll starve and become unhappy.
LanguageData.GroupGotoHereDragging.label: Positioning fighters
LanguageData.GroupGotoHereDragging.helpText: Right-click and drag to have your drafted fighters form a line.\n\nSpread out - bunched-up targets are easy to hit!
LanguageData.BuildOrbitalTradeBeacon.label: Build orbital trade beacon
LanguageData.BuildOrbitalTradeBeacon.helpText: To send items or silver to orbital traders, you must build an ORBITAL TRADE BEACON and place a stockpile of items near it.
LanguageData.AnimalsDontAttackDoors.label: Animals will attack doors
LanguageData.AnimalsDontAttackDoors.helpText: Manhunting animals will attack doors if they see one of your colonists moving through them. They will also attack inactive turrets.
LanguageData.BillsTab.label: Bills tab
LanguageData.BillsTab.helpText: To make colonists work at a table, select the table and open the Bills tab. Here, you can say what meals to cook, what things to craft, what creatures to butcher.
LanguageData.OpeningComms.label: Using the comms console
LanguageData.OpeningComms.helpText: To communicate, select a colonist and right-click on the comms console.
LanguageData.DrugAddiction.label: Drug addiction
LanguageData.DrugAddiction.helpText:
You can inspect your colonists' desire to take a drug in their Needs tab.

As long as their need level is at zero, their addiction changes to a "withdrawal" state which can have various negative side effects.

However, after long enough in withdrawal, their addiction will end and the drug need will disappear.
LanguageData.DrugPolicies.label: Drug policies
LanguageData.DrugPolicies.helpText:
You can assign colonists to take specific drugs on a specific schedule. For example, you can make them take infection-blocking drugs regularly, or drink a beer a day to stay happy.

Open the ASSIGN tab and press the 'Manage drug policies' button. Create a new drug policy. Then, you can assign this policy to colonists.

Colonists can still take drugs not in their policy. You can tell them what to do, but they also follow their own desires!
LanguageData.TVForSickPeople.label: TV for sick people
LanguageData.TVForSickPeople.helpText: Sick people can watch TV while laying in bed.
LanguageData.PrisonerTab.label: Prisoner tab
LanguageData.PrisonerTab.helpText:
Look in a prisoner's 'Prisoner' tab to set how they'll be treated.

You can set whether they'll be recruited, ignored or executed, whether they eat, and what kind of medical care they get.

Colonists with the Warden work type will interact with the prisoner.
LanguageData.SetGrowingZonePlant.label: Set what plant to grow
LanguageData.SetGrowingZonePlant.helpText: You can set what to plant in a growing zone. You can even grow trees!\n\nJust select the growing zone, open the Growing tab, and click the 'plant' button.
LanguageData.DrugBurning.label: Drug burning
LanguageData.DrugBurning.helpText: Drugs can be useful, but can also lead to harmful addictions.\n\nIf you want to avoid drugs in your colony, you have the option of burning them at a campfire.
LanguageData.DoorOpenSpeed.label: Door opening speeds
LanguageData.DoorOpenSpeed.helpText: Doors open at different speeds depending on what they're made of.\n\nWarning: Stone doors open very slowly. Anyone passing through will be significantly slowed down.
LanguageData.QueueOrders.label: Order queueing
LanguageData.QueueOrders.helpText: When giving commands to pawns, you can queue up multiple orders by holding "shift". This also works when giving jobs to undrafted pawns.
LanguageData.CameraDolly.label: Camera dolly
LanguageData.CameraDolly.helpText: Move the camera by clicking and dragging the MOUSE BUTTON 3 (middle button) or with the {Key:MapDolly_Up}-{Key:MapDolly_Left}-{Key:MapDolly_Down}-{Key:MapDolly_Right} keys.
LanguageData.CameraZoom.label: Camera zoom
LanguageData.CameraZoom.helpText: Zoom in and out with the MOUSEWHEEL or the {Key:MapZoom_In} and {Key:MapZoom_Out} keys.
LanguageData.TimeControls.label: Time controls
LanguageData.TimeControls.helpText: You can speed up time.\n\nTry controlling time with the {Key:TimeSpeed_Normal}, {Key:TimeSpeed_Fast}, and {Key:TimeSpeed_Superfast} keys, or with the time controls in the bottom right.
LanguageData.Pause.label: Pausing
LanguageData.Pause.helpText:
Hit {Key:TogglePause} to pause or unpause the game.

You can give orders while paused.

Remember this - if things get hectic, just hit {Key:TogglePause}!
LanguageData.Stockpiles.label: Stockpiles
LanguageData.Stockpiles.helpText: Your colonists need somewhere to store items. Designate a STOCKPILE for them to store things.\n\nFind the stockpile in the ZONES section of the ARCHITECT menu in the lower-left.
LanguageData.Forbidding.label: Forbid and allow
LanguageData.Forbidding.helpText: Colonists will not interact with items marked FORBIDDEN.\n\nForbidden items have a small red X attached. Select a forbidden item and use the controls at the bottom to ALLOW it.
LanguageData.GrowingFood.label: Growing zones
LanguageData.GrowingFood.helpText: To grow food, place GROWING ZONES using the Architect menu.\n\nThey can only be placed on fertile ground.
LanguageData.EquippingWeapons.label: Equipping weapons
LanguageData.EquippingWeapons.helpText: Your colonists arrived with some weapons. Equip them!\n\nSelect each colonist and right-click on the weapon you want them to equip.
LanguageData.Alerts.label: Alerts
LanguageData.Alerts.helpText: The alerts at the right edge of the screen tell you about issues that need your attention.\n\nKeep an eye on the alerts.
LanguageData.Mining.label: Mining
LanguageData.Mining.helpText: You can designate where to mine by opening the ARCHITECT menu and selecting the ORDERS tab.\n\nSome mineable blocks yield STEEL, GOLD, PLASTEEL, and other useful materials.
LanguageData.WorkTab.label: Work settings
LanguageData.WorkTab.helpText:
You can set each colonist's work settings in the WORK tab at the bottom left of the screen.

They will always do the highest priority work that they can find.

If nobody has a certain work type assigned, or if they are busy with higher-priority tasks, it will never get done.
LanguageData.ForbiddingDoors.label: Forbidding doors
LanguageData.ForbiddingDoors.helpText: You can FORBID doors so colonists and tame animals won't go through them.\n\nNote that this isn't a door lock. Doors are always locked, so enemies can't pass freely. Forbidding just directs your colonists not to use the door. Colonists who are going crazy might use the door anyway.
LanguageData.CoverAndShooting.label: Cover and shooting
LanguageData.CoverAndShooting.helpText:
The most important thing to do in ranged combat is to use cover.

Cover only works if your colonist is touching it, and it is between your colonist and the enemy.

You can also place colonists behind wall corners. They will lean out to shoot.

Most things can be used as cover, but some things are better than others. Hiding behind a tree is better than nothing, but hiding behind sandbags is better than using a tree.
LanguageData.FormCaravan.label: Forming caravans
LanguageData.FormCaravan.helpText: You can form a caravan to send groups of people traveling across the planet!\n\nIn the WORLD tab, select your home base and click the "form caravan" button.
LanguageData.AnimalTaming.label: Animal taming
LanguageData.AnimalTaming.helpText:
You can assign colonists to tame a wild animal with the TAME designator.

Colonists will offer the animal food and attempt to tame it.

Beware: Some animals can respond violently to failed taming attempts.
LanguageData.AnimalTraining.label: Animal training
LanguageData.AnimalTraining.helpText: You can assign a tame animal to be trained in specific skills on its TRAINING tab.\n\nAnimals can't be trained continuously; they need time between training sessions.
LanguageData.InfoCard.label: Info card
LanguageData.InfoCard.helpText: The info card shows you detailed statistics about any item, person, or construction.\n\nSelect a person or item and open their info card with the 'i' button on the inspect pane.
LanguageData.StorageTab.label: Storage tab
LanguageData.StorageTab.helpText:
You can configure stockpiles and storage buildings by selecting them and opening the STORAGE TAB above the bottom-left inspector pane.

In the storage tab of a stockpile, you can expand categories to allow or deny specific items. Click the triangles to the left of category names.

You can change the PRIORITY of storage. Colonists will fill higher-priority storage first, and move items from lower to higher priority.
LanguageData.HomeArea.label: Home area
LanguageData.HomeArea.helpText: The HOME AREA tells your colonists which area to clean and where to extinguish fires.\n\nDefine the HOME AREA with the Zones category under the Architect menu.
LanguageData.SpoilageAndFreezers.label: Spoilage and freezers
LanguageData.SpoilageAndFreezers.helpText:
Most foodstuffs will spoil after a relatively short time.

To prevent this, you can build a walk-in freezer.

To build a freezer, construct a closed room, and put one or two coolers into the wall. Set the coolers to a negative target temperature.

Frozen foods won't ever spoil.
LanguageData.Deterioration.label: Item deterioration
LanguageData.Deterioration.helpText: Items left outdoors will slowly deteriorate.\n\nIf you want to store items long-term, keep them in a roofed room.
LanguageData.HostilityResponse.label: Hostility response modes
LanguageData.HostilityResponse.helpText: You can configure how colonists should automatically respond to threats like predatory animals.\n\nChoose from FLEE, ATTACK, and IGNORE modes in the ASSIGN menu.
LanguageData.AllowedAreas.label: Allowed areas
LanguageData.AllowedAreas.helpText:
Colonists and colony animals can be assigned to ALLOWED AREAS. This forbids them from taking destinations outside their allowed area.

This can be used to, for example, forbid colonists from going outside.

You can create multiple allowed areas and assign them to different colonists and animals.

Create, delete, and assign allowed areas in the RESTRICT tab.

Paint allowed areas onto the map using the EXPAND ALLOWED AREA and CLEAR ALLOWED AREA designators in the Architect tab.
LanguageData.MedicalOperations.label: Medical operations
LanguageData.MedicalOperations.helpText: To assign a medical operation, like organ harvesting or prosthetics installation, open a colonist's HEALTH tab, then switch to the OPERATIONS sub-tab.
LanguageData.TimeAssignments.label: Time assignments
LanguageData.TimeAssignments.helpText: You can modify what time of day colonists should do different activities using the RESTRICT tab.
LanguageData.ManualWorkPriorities.label: Manual work priorities
LanguageData.ManualWorkPriorities.helpText:
One of the most important parts of RimWorld is choosing good work settings for your colonists.

Poor work settings can leave essential work unfinished for a long time while colonists waste time on unimportant tasks.

To give more control over what work colonists do, you can use the Manual Priorities mode in the WORK tab.

In this mode, each colonist has a priority number for each work type. Colonists will do priority 1 work from left to right, then priority 2 work from left to right, and so on.

Intelligent use of these setting is essential for a large, well-automated colony.
LanguageData.GettingMoreTraders.label: Getting more traders
LanguageData.GettingMoreTraders.helpText:
More trader caravans will come to visit you if you're allied with more factions.

If you have no allies, no caravans will ever visit!

You can also pay allies to send trade caravans by calling them on the comms console.
LanguageData.InspectRoomStats.label: Room stats inspector
LanguageData.InspectRoomStats.helpText: You can inspect the impressiveness, wealth, and beauty of individual rooms using the ROOM STATS INSPECT toggle in the bottom right.
LanguageData.Outfits.label: Outfits
LanguageData.Outfits.helpText:
Colonists will automatically try to wear the newest, highest-quality apparel they can.

You don't need to manually assign each piece of apparel to colonists (though you can, if you wish).

To assign colonists restrictions on how to dress, open the ASSIGN tab, use the "Manage outfits" dialog box to design a new outfit, and then assign the outfit to colonists.
LanguageData.FirePreparation.label: Fire preparation
LanguageData.FirePreparation.helpText:
Fires can easily burn down a colony. To defeat them, you must prepare before they happen. 
These design elements can help reduce the damage from fires: 
1. Instead of constructing one super-building, build separate buildings with spaces in between. 
2. Use less flammable materials. Wood is cheap and fast - but very flammable. 
3. Build firebreaks to stop wildfires approaching your base. A strip of concrete floor 3 or 4 cells wide will generally stop an advancing fire.
LanguageData.HistoryTab.label: History tab
LanguageData.HistoryTab.helpText: You can see a record of your colony's fortunes over time in the HISTORY tab at the bottom of the screen.
LanguageData.ClickingMessages.label: Clicking messages
LanguageData.ClickingMessages.helpText: You can click on the notifications in the top-left of the screen to instantly center the camera on their subject.
LanguageData.ShotAccuracyTooltip.label: Shot accuracy tooltip
LanguageData.ShotAccuracyTooltip.helpText: You can see the exact calculations behind the accuracy of any shot.\n\nTo do so, select the shooter, then rest the mouse over the target. The tooltip will show the chance to hit, and a breakdown of the contribution of various to-hit chance multipliers.
LanguageData.FriendlyFireSafety.label: Friendly fire safety
LanguageData.FriendlyFireSafety.helpText:
Friendly fire never occurs if the shooter is close to their ally.

For example, you can safely put a sword-wielding colonist directly in front of a gun-wielding one. The shooter will fire over his friend's shoulder.

This is a good way to combine ranged and melee fighters.
LanguageData.TradeGoodsMustBeNearBeacon.label: Trade goods and trade beacons
LanguageData.TradeGoodsMustBeNearBeacon.helpText: To send items or silver to orbital traders, you must build an ORBITAL TRADE BEACON and place a stockpile of items near it.
LanguageData.ArrestingCreatesEnemies.label: Arresting worsens faction relations
LanguageData.ArrestingCreatesEnemies.helpText:
Warning: The person you are trying to arrest may not go quietly.

If you arrest a non-colonist or a colonist from another faction, their entire faction may become your enemy. 

This arrest has a {0} chance of succeeding, based on the social skill of the arrester.
LanguageData.SwitchFlickingDesignation.label: Flick designations only designate
LanguageData.SwitchFlickingDesignation.helpText: Note: This only designates that a colonist should flick the switch.\n\nNothing will actually happen until a colonist comes and flicks the switch by hand.
LanguageData.MaxNumberOfPlayerSettlements.label: Maximum number of player colonies
LanguageData.MaxNumberOfPlayerSettlements.helpText:
Warning: RimWorld is designed to be played with one player colony at a time. Multiple player colonies are allowed as an experimental testing feature only.

Playing with multiple colonies will cause gameplay imbalances and split your focus, as well as likely causing performance slowdowns.

We recommend that you play with the one-colony maximum the game was designed for, at least for your first few games.
LanguageData.TradingRequiresPermit.label: Trading permit requirements
LanguageData.TradingRequiresPermit.helpText: Trading here requires the title of {0}.\n\nEnsure any trade caravan you send has someone with the title of {0} or higher.
